article_text: Twenty-first-century elites have assembled a remarkable collection of moral pieties around both eating and parenting. So it should come as no surprise that at the intersection of the two lies arguably the most strident piety of all: breast-feeding. Today, the overwhelming consensus is that breast is best, as Courtney Jung documents in “Lactivism: How Feminists and Fundamentalists, Hippies and Yuppies, and Physicians and Politicians Made Breastfeeding Big Business and Bad Policy.” Nursing is no longer just a way to feed a baby. These days, Ms. Jung writes, it’s “a way of showing the world who you are and what you...

article_summary:
These days, Ms. Jung writes, it’s “a way of showing the world who you are and what you...
So it should come as no surprise that at the intersection of the two lies arguably the most strident piety of all: breast-feeding.
Twenty-first-century elites have assembled a remarkable collection of moral pieties around both eating and parenting.
Today, the overwhelming consensus is that breast is best, as Courtney Jung documents in “Lactivism: How Feminists and Fundamentalists, Hippies and Yuppies, and Physicians and Politicians Made Breastfeeding Big Business and Bad Policy.” Nursing is no longer just a way to feed a baby.
